thread.title_full: MONA's Mofo promises to ramp up the beats with a percussion theme to next festival

author: Andrew Stephens
title: MONA's Mofo promises to ramp up the beats with a percussion theme to next festival
text:
Maggie Abraham (left) and Tracey Patten performed at the launch of the Mofo program in Hobart on Friday. 
Being rained on by an artwork while also making musical art: it was a classic MONA experience.
At Friday's launch of the next Mona Foma festival of music and art in January, percussionists Tracey Patten and Maggie Abraham were completely drenched as they did an enthusiastic performance under the Bit.Fall water sculpture by German-born artist Julius Popp.
Fluffy white towels were on hand, as was Violent Femmes' Brian Ritchie, the acclaimed US musician and bass player who now lives in Tasmania and has been curating the festival since 2009.
The launch took place at MONA's Bit.Fall sculpture. 
And the point of all that water making a loud splash on the drummers and their kits? The new Mofo, says Ritchie, is to be all about percussion.
Advertisement Ritchie said percussion has been assailed in recent years by computerised competitors, so he is focussing Mofo on the human-made beat, with percussive soloists being a strong element.
One of the highlights of Mofo, he said, will be the solo Scottish percussionist Evelyn Glennie, who is deaf – making her interpretation of drumming especially fascinating.
There will also be the Flaming Lips, DJ Krush and composer Antonio Sanchez, who will do a live performance at MONA of his soundtrack for the film Birdman .
Mofo will coincide with MONA's much-awaited the Art Exhibition by infamous British artists Gilbert & George.
For the first time, Mofo will have its hub at MONA, rather than in central Hobart, and about 5000 people are expected to enjoy the many events at various venues – even at the MONA ferry terminal.
Ritchie said Mofo was being held at MONA because its many interesting spaces had wonderful acoustics – and he didn't want to get complacent about the tone or geographics of the festival.
"We pride ourselves on the unexpected," he said. "We don't want to get formulaic. We'll be able to have people on the lawn, inside the site, all over MONA. People will be able to get a diverse experience."
Mona Foma takes place over January 13-18, see  www.mofo.net.au
